column1: CDC study finds Moderna vaccine is best at preventing Covid-19 hospitalization - POLITICO
['\nThe Moderna vaccine also produced higher post-vaccination antibody levels than the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine
column6: 'Moderna’s Covid-19 vaccine is the most effective at protecting against Covid-19 hospitalizations
column7: according to a study published Friday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.'
column9: 600 adults hospitalized at 21 U.S. facilities from March to August found that vaccine efficacy against hospitalization was 93 percent for the Moderna vaccine compared to 88 percent for the Pfizer-BioNTech shot.'
column10: 'The effectiveness of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine declined significantly after 120 days
column12: although it still provided strong protection against severe disease.'
column13: 'The Moderna vaccine also produced higher post-vaccination antibody levels than the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine
column16: 'The CDC has released several studies looking at vaccine efficacy in particular groups
column17: such as frontline health care workers
column18: as the administration prepares to roll out boosters to at least some adults in the coming weeks. While some of those studies have included data on efficacy of the various vaccines
column19: the study published Friday offers greater insight into the extent to which Moderna
column20: Pfizer-BioNTech and Johnson & Johnson protect against severe disease and Covid-19 hospitalization.'
column21: 'The data from the recent CDC cohort study suggests that the two-dose Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine regimens protect better against hospitalization than the single-dose Johnson & Johnson shot. However
column22: the Johnson & Johnson vaccine still reduced risk of Covid-19-related hospitalization by 71 percent.'
column23: 'Although the efficacy of the vaccines varied
column24: the CDC study showed that all of the FDA-approved Covid-19 vaccines still work well at protecting against Covid-19 hospitalization.']
